content.text:
# 2027 French presidential election__disambig_1

Presidential elections are scheduled to be held in France in or around April 2027, with a second round two weeks later if  no candidate secures a majority vote. The elections may be held earlier under exceptional circumstances if the presidency falls vacant before then. The incumbent president, Emmanuel Macron, is term-limited and cannot seek a third consecutive term in office. However, he has hinted the possibility of running in the 2032 elections, which would make him eligible.
Electoral system
The president of the French Republic is elected to a five-year term under the two-round system as stipulated in Article 7 of the French Constitution. If no candidate secures an absolute majority (50% + 1) of votes in the first round, including blank and void ballots, a second round is held two weeks later between the two candidates who received the most votes. Per the constitution, the first round of the presidential election must be held between 20 and 35 days before the conclusion of the president's current five-year term. Emmanuel Macron's second term, which began on 14 May 2022, is scheduled to end on 13 May 2027, meaning that the first round of the presidential election is scheduled to be held between 8 and 23 April 2027.
To be listed on the first-round ballot, candidates must secure 500 signatures (often referred to as ) from national or local elected officials from at least 30 different departments or overseas collectivities, with no more than a tenth of these signatories from any single department. According to the Article 6 of the French constitution, the president cannot "exercise more than two consecutive periods in office".
Declared candidates
Horizons
* Édouard Philippe, Prime Minister of France (2017–2020); Mayor of Le Havre (2010–2017; 2020–present); Deputy for Seine-Maritime's 7th constituency (2012–2017)
Édouard Philippe à Châlons-en-Champagne en 2023. (cropped).jpg|Former Prime MinisterÉdouard Philippe
The Republicans
* Xavier Bertrand, President of the Regional Council of Hauts-de-France (2016–present); Deputy for Aisne's 2nd constituency (2002–2016)
* David Lisnard, Mayor of Cannes (2014–present); Departmental Councillor of Alpes-Maritimes (2008–present)
* Laurent Wauquiez, President of the Regional Council of Auvergne-Rhône-Alpes (2016–2024); Deputy for Haute-Loire's 1st constituency (2004–2007; 2012–2017; 2024–present); President of The Republicans (2017–2019)
File:Xavier Bertrand - 2025 (cropped).jpg|Regional Council PresidentXavier Bertrandof Hauts-de-France
File:David Lisnard - 2013.jpg|MayorDavid Lisnardof Cannes
File:Laurent Wauquiez 2021.jpg|Former Regional Council PresidentLaurent Wauquiezof Auvergne-Rhône-Alpes
Socialist Party
* Ségolène Royal, Minister of Ecology, Sustainable Development and Energy (2014–2017); President of the Regional Council of Poitou-Charentes (2004–2014); Socialist Party nominee in the 2007 presidential election; Deputy for Deux-Sèvres's 2nd constituency (1988–1992; 1993–1997; 2002–2007)
File:Royal Toulouse 2012.JPG|Former Ecology MinisterSégolène Royal
Others
* François Asselineau (Popular Republican Union), President of the Popular Republican Union (2007–present); Councillor of Paris (2000–2008)
* Clémentine Autain (L'Après), Deputy for Seine-Saint-Denis's 11th constituency (2017–present)
* Nicolas Dupont-Aignan (Debout la France), President of Debout la France (2008–present); Municipal Councillor of Yerres (1995–present); Deputy for Essonne's 8th constituency (1997–2024)
* François Ruffin (Debout !), President of Debout ! (2025–present); Deputy for Somme's 1st constituency (2017–present)
File:François ASSELINEAU.jpg|Former CouncillorFrançois Asselineauof Paris
File:Clementine-Autain.jpg|DeputyClémentine Autainfor Seine-Saint-Denis's 11th constituency
File:Nicolas Dupont-Aignan, homme politique français (cropped).jpg|Former DeputyNicolas Dupont-Aignanfor Essonne's 8th constituency
File:François Ruffin (cropped).jpg|DeputyFrançois Ruffinfor Somme's 1st constituency
Potential candidates
Reconquête
* Éric Zemmour, President of Reconquête (2021–present); Reconquête nominee in the 2022 presidential election; journalist
File:Éric Zemmour, BFM TV, mai 2022 (52121678246).jpg|JournalistÉric Zemmour
National Rally
* Jordan Bardella, MEP for France (2019–present); President of National Rally (2022–present)
File:MEP Jordan Bardella.jpg|MEPJordan Bardellafor France
The Republicans
* Michel Barnier, Prime Minister of France (2024); MEP for Île-de-France (2009–2010)
* Valérie Pécresse, President of the Regional Council of Île-de-France (2015–present); The Republicans nominee in the 2022 presidential election; Deputy for Yvelines's 2nd constituency (2002–2007; 2012–2016)
* Bruno Retailleau, Minister of State, Minister of the Interior (2024–present); President of The Republicans (2025–present); Senator for Vendée (2004–2024)
File:Barnier Portrait.jpg|Former Prime MinisterMichel Barnier
File:Valérie Pécresse - (32605116257) (cropped).jpg|Regional Council PresidentValérie Pécresseof Île-de-France
File:Bruno Retailleau - Ministre de l'Intérieur français (cropped).jpg|Interior MinisterBruno Retailleau
Renaissance
* Gabriel Attal, Prime Minister of France (2024); Deputy for Hauts-de-Seine's 10th constituency (2017–2018; 2022; 2024–present); General Secretary of Renaissance (2024–present)
* Élisabeth Borne, Prime Minister of France (2022–2024); Minister of National Education, Higher Education and Research, Minister of State (2024–present); Deputy for Calvados's 6th constituency (2022; 2024–2025)
* Yaël Braun-Pivet, President of the National Assembly (2022–present); Deputy for Yvelines's 5th constituency (2017–present)
* Jean Castex, Prime Minister of France (2020–2022); Mayor of Prades (2008–2020)
* Gérald Darmanin, Keeper of the Seals, Minister of Justice, Minister of State (2024–present); Deputy for Nord's 10th constituency (2012–2016; 2022; 2024–2025)
File:Gabriel Attal 2025 (close crop).jpg|Former Prime MinisterGabriel Attal
File:Elisabeth Borne November 2022 close-up.jpg|Former Prime MinisterÉlisabeth Borne
File:Yaël Braun-Pivet 2023 (cropped).jpg|National Assembly PresidentYaël Braun-Pivet
File:Portrait_Jean_Castex_(cropped).jpg|Former Prime MinisterJean Castex
File:Gérald Darmanin in 2022.jpg|Justice MinisterGérald Darmanin
Democratic Movement
* François Bayrou, Prime Minister of France (2024–2025); President of the Democratic Movement (2007–present); Mayor of Pau (2014–present)
File:François Bayrou 2025 (cropped).jpg|Former Prime Minister François Bayrou
Socialist Party
* Bernard Cazeneuve, Prime Minister of France (2016–2017); Deputy for Manche's 4th constituency (2012; 2017); Deputy for Manche's 5th constituency (1997–2002; 2007–2012)
* Carole Delga, President of the Regional Council of Occitania (2016–present); Deputy for Haute-Garonne's 8th constituency (2012–2014; 2015–2017)
* Olivier Faure, First Secretary of the Socialist Party (2018–present); Deputy for Seine-et-Marne's 11th constituency (2012–present)
* Raphaël Glucksmann, Member of the European Parliament (2019–present); co-president of Place Publique (2018–present)
* François Hollande, President of France (2012–2017); Deputy for Corrèze's 1st constituency (1988–1993; 1997–2012; 2024–present); First Secretary of the Socialist Party (1997–2008)
File:Bernard_Cazeneuve,_(42399145362)_(cropped).jpg|Former Prime MinisterBernard Cazeneuve
File:Delga-Toulouse-Occitanie (cropped).jpg|Regional Council PresidentCarole Delgaof Occitania
File:Olivier Faure PSE-CARCA--1194 (cropped).jpg|DeputyOlivier Faurefor Seine-et-Marne's 11th constituency
File:1720448398743 20240708 GLUCKSMANN Raphael FR 006.jpg|MEPRaphaël Glucksmann
File:François_Hollande_-_2017_(27869823159)_(cropped_2).jpg|Former PresidentFrançois Hollande
La France Insoumise
* Manuel Bompard, Deputy for Bouches-du-Rhône's 4th constituency (2022–present); MEP for France (2019–2022)
* Jean-Luc Mélenchon, Deputy for Bouches-du-Rhône's 4th constituency (2017–2022); MEP for France (2009–2017); La France Insoumise nominee in the 2017 and 2022 presidential elections
* Mathilde Panot, Deputy for Val-de-Marne's 10th constituency (2017–present)
File:Bompard MEP 2019.jpg|DeputyManuel Bompardfor Bouches-du-Rhône's 4th constituency
File:Jean-Luc Mélenchon 2022 (cropped).jpg|Former DeputyJean-Luc Mélenchonfor Bouches-du-Rhône's 4th constituency
File:Mathilde Panot 2021-3.jpg|DeputyMathilde Panotfor Val-de-Marne's 10th constituency
Others
* Dominique de Villepin, Prime Minister of France (2005–2007); leader of Humanist France (2025–present)
File:Launch Republique Solidaire 2010-06-19 n04.jpg|Former Prime MinisterDominique de Villepin
Disqualified candidates
National Rally
* Marine Le Pen, Deputy for Pas-de-Calais's 11th constituency (2017–present); President of the National Rally (2011–2021); National Rally nominee in the 2012, 2017, and 2022 presidential elections; MEP for Île-de-France (2004–2009); MEP for North-West France (2009–2017)
**Le Pen was convicted of embezzlement in 2025, and subsequently disqualified from presidential politics and banned from running for political office for five years, for using European Parliament funds to fund National Rally staff. The Court of Appeal will rule on her case in summer 2026, confirming whether she can run in 2027 or not.
File:Marine Le Pen 2025 (cropped).jpg|DeputyMarine Le Penfor Pas-de-Calais's 11th constituency
Declined to be candidates
*Éric Ciotti (Union of the Right for the Republic), Deputy for Alpes-Maritimes's 1st constituency (2007–present); President of The Republicans (2022–2024) (endorsed Marine Le Pen)
*Cyril Hanouna (Independent), television presenter
*Sarah Knafo (Reconquête), MEP for France (2024–present) (endorsed Éric Zemmour)
*Bruno Le Maire (Renaissance), Minister of Economics and Finance (2017–2024); Deputy for Eure's 1st constituency (2007–2009; 2012–2017; 2017)
*Marion Maréchal (Identity–Liberties), MEP for France (2024–present); Deputy for Vaucluse's 3rd constituency (2012–2017)
*Robert Ménard (Independent), Mayor of Béziers (2014–present)
*Philippe Poutou (New Anticapitalist Party), Municipal Councillor of Bordeaux (2020–present)
